data.title: Sommerfeld: the Eternal Nobel Candidate
data.meta_description: Sommerfeld is one of the great names in physics but, despite his achievements, he never received the Nobel Prize in Physics, although he got 84 nominations
data.text:
In late 1928, a famous German physicist wrote to one of his colleagues to tell him with chagrin that he had once again been passed over for the Nobel Prize in Physics:

âBut to dispel all suspicion of false modesty, I must simultaneously note that it is gradually becoming a public scandal that I have still not received the Prize [Nobel Prize in Physics].” (1)

The theoretical physicistÂ Arnold SommerfeldÂ (1868-1951) was born in KÃ¶nigsberg, a city in what was formerly East Prussia, today Kaliningrad in Russia, and also the birthplace of the mathematiciansÂ Christian GoldbachÂ andÂ David Hilbert, the philosopherÂ Immanuel KantÂ and the writerÂ E. T. A. Hoffmann. After receiving his doctorate from the University of KÃ¶nigsberg in 1891, he moved to the University of GÃ¶ttingen, the mecca of mathematics in Germany at that time, where he eventually became assistant to the mathematicianÂ Felix KleinÂ and gave classes on mathematics and theoretical physics. After spending some years at RWTH Aachen University, in 1906 he succeededÂ Ludwig BoltzmannÂ as professor of theoretical physics and director of the Institute of Theoretical Physics at the University of Munich, where he set up a school of theoretical physics which gained worldwide renown.

Arnold Sommerfeld, who was ten years younger thanÂ Max PlanckÂ (1858-1947) and a little over ten years older thanÂ Albert EinsteinÂ (1879-1955), was part ofÂ a brilliant generation of German physicists who endured military defeat in the Great War, the fall of the German Empire, the birth of the Weimar republic, Hitlerâs arrival in power and the Second World War, but who âin spite of those turbulent yearsâ made a decisive contribution to theÂ birth,Â development and consolidation of quantum physics.

Elliptical orbits for Bohrâs atomic model

Sommerfeld made major contributions to the field of mathematical diffraction theory, although his most important legacy is what is known asÂ Sommerfeld’s atomic model. In 1915, Sommerfeld developed his own version of Niels Bohrâs atomic modelÂ (published two years earlier). Although Bohrâs model worked for the hydrogen atom âthat is, an atom with a single electronâ it was unable to explain the behavior of atoms with more than one electron. To resolve this situation, Sommerfeld considered elliptical orbits as well as the circular orbits in Bohrâs model, and took account of the fact that in some atoms the electrons moved at relativist speeds. Â Sommerfeldâs atomic model, a generalization of Bohrâs model, combined concepts of classical physics and Planckâs quantum theory, and was one of the most important consequences of the âold quantum theoryâ.

All the secrets of the hydrogen atom revealed

One of Sommerfeldâs most spectacular successes was his study of hydrogen-like atoms within the framework of the theory of special relativity, which offered a theoretical explanation of the fine structure of the hydrogen atom.Â In 1916 he introduced theÂ fine-structure constantÂ ( a = 1/137), as a relativist measure of the deviations in the spectral lines of atoms in the predictions made by Bohrâs model, but which over the years became used to characterize the force of the electromagnetic interaction between charged elementary particles in quantum electrodynamics. Sommerfeldâs model (or Bohr-Sommerfeldâs model) remained valid until the advent of quantum mechanics which started to unfold in around 1920, thanks to the contribution of established physicists like SchrÃ¶dinger and Born, and of other younger physicists such as Dirac, de Broglie, Pauli, Heisenberg, and others). SchrÃ¶dingerâs wave equation and the probabilistic interpretation of Bornâs wave function marked the definitive retirement of Bohr-Sommerfeldâs atomic model, in spite of its success in describing the spectrum of the hydrogen atom.

Sommerfeld, youâve been nominated

Notwithstanding his important scientific contributions, Sommerfeld never received the Nobel Prize in Physics, although he was responsible for a series of major achievements that amply justified the award, and also created several records related to the prize that would be very hard to beat:

He is the physicist with highest number of doctoral students who were awarded a Nobel prize, namely four (Werner Heisenberg,Â Wolfgang Pauli,Â Peter DebyeÂ andÂ Hans Bethe).

He received the most nominations for the Nobel Prize in Physics, specificallyÂ 84 between 1917 and 1951Â (more than any other physicist, includingÂ Otto Stern,Â who comes second with 82 nominations, but who was eventually awarded the prize).

In 1929 he received nine nominations, including those of three Nobel Prize winners in Physics: Max Planck, James Franck and Max von Laue.

The fact that 21 of his doctoral students made important contributions in their fields of specialization, that three of his postgraduate students also won the Nobel Prize (Linus Pauling,Â Isidor RabiÂ andÂ Max von Laue), while another three were famous in their respective areas of research, all helps explain whyÂ Max BornÂ (1882-1970) said that Sommerfeldâs skills included theÂ “discovery and development of talent”, and why Albert Einstein himself on one occasion said to Sommerfeld:

âWhat I especially admire about you is the way, at a stamp of your foot, a great number of talented young theorists spring up out of the ground.â (1)

Michael Eckert, in his biography entitled âArnold Sommerfeld: Science, Life and Turbulent Times 1868-1951â, rightly concludes that:

âPlanck was the authority, Einstein the genius, and Sommerfeld the teacher.â

In 1949, two years before his death, Sommerfeld received theÂ Oersted Medal in recognition of outstanding contributions to the field of physics teaching. That same year, in an article published in the journalÂ American Journal of Physics, he confessed that this recognition of his teaching activity was one of the things that had given him most pleasure in the whole of his scientific career. On March 28, 1951, while he was walking near his house in Munich, Arnold Sommerfield was knocked down by a car, and ten days later lost consciousness and died on April 26, 1951. On the following day his son Ernst wrote (1):

âWe believe he was spared the sorrow of becoming separated from his beloved physics and from his family and friends.â

Even in the year of his death, Sommerfeld (with four more nominations) was again nominated for the Nobel Prize in Physics. This would be the last time.
